page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: Dunster lies on the edge of Exmoor, encircled on three sides by steep wooded hills, the fourth side forms part of a flat coastal strip, across which the river Avill flows into the Bistol Channel. Four factors contribute to a settlement being built up at Dunster: the local geography, the river Avill, the castle and to some extent the Priory. Dunster is one of the villages which are typical of England as it used to be, for it is one of the finest examples of a medieval village or small town left in the West Country. Many tourists visit it every year yet it has still managed to remain virtually unspoilt.
